\end{array}$

question: Find the integral curve which satisfies the equation $tx'-x=-2t^2x^2$ with initial condition $x(1)=1$.
answer1: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $x(2t^3+1)-3t=0$.
answer2: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $x(2t^3+3)-t=0$.
answer3: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $\frac{x}{2t^3+1}-3t=0$.
answer4: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $x=\frac{2t^3+1}{3t}$.

question:
Describe the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & = & 4 \\
x & + & 3y & - & z & = & 11 \\
2x & + & 5y & - & 5z & = & 13 \\
x & + & 4y & + & z & = & 18
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The linear system has $\left(4,\,3,\,2\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer2: The linear system has $\left(4,\,2,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(2z,\,z+1,\,z\right)$ for each $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x &+ &y &- &z &= &1 \\ 
x &+ &y &+ &z &= &2 \\ 
x &- &y &- &z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(1,0,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,0,1\right)$ and $\left(1,0,-1\right)$ as its solutions.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,0,x\right)$ as solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c}
\text{Plant Dist. Center} & \text{1} & \text{2} & \text{3}  & \text{4}  \\
\text{1} & 800  & 1300 &  400 & 700\\
\text{2} & 1100 & 1400 &  600 & 1000 \\
\text{3} & 600  & 1200 &  800 & 900\\
\end{array}
\]	

The freight cost for each shipment is $100.50?$ per mile. Use the transportation simplex method to determine how much should be shipped from each plant to each of the distribution centers each month, to minimize the total shipping cost. Use the minimum cost rule to obtain an initial basic feasible solution.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & + & 2z & = & a \\
x & + & 2y & + & z & = & b \\
x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\
4x & + & 3y & + & 4z & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has solutions if and only if $a=-2$ and $b=5$. 
In this case, there is an infinite number of solution, which are of the form $\left(x,\,4,\,-3-x\right)$ for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer2:
The system has solutions if and only if $a \neq \frac{7}{4}$ and $b \neq \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the solutions are of the form $\left(\frac{3}{4}a-z,\,\frac{1}{4}b,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
The system has solutions if and only if $a = \frac{7}{4}$ and $b = \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the unique solution is $\left(\frac{3}{4},\,\frac{1}{4},\,0\right)$.

x & + & 5y & + & 5z & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(0,\,0,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:

$$\begin{cases}
(1+i)z& + & (1-i)w & = & i \\
(1-i)z& + & (1+i)w & = & 1-i
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has the vector $(i,-i)$ has its unique solution.

question:
Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{C}^2\right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
z &- &iw &= &1 \\
iz &- &w &= &1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\bigg(\frac{1-i}{2},\frac{-1+i}{2}\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer3: The system has $(z,-iz)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer4: The system has $\bigg(\frac{1-i}{2},\frac{1+i}{2}\bigg)$ as unique solution.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & y & - & 3z & + & 2t & = & 1 \\
2x & - & y & - & z & + & t & = & 0 \\
x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{4}t-\frac{7}{12},\frac{3}{4}t-\frac{3}{4},t\bigg)$, for all $t\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},-\frac{7}{12},-\frac{3}{4},0\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer4: The solution of the system is the vector of coordinates $(2,-1,0,0)$.

answer4: $x$ is the number of workers in each shift;

question: Choose two vectors of $V=\left\{(-10,5),(2,-1),(-5,1),(2,0),\left(\dfrac{1}{2},2\right),\left(2,\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\right\}$ which are linearly dependent.

A consulting firm will carry out two types of projects ($A$ and $B$). The development cost per project $A$ and $B$ is, respectively, $1$ and $2$ monetary units. The requirements in terms of analysts, programmers and terminals for each type of project, are indicated in the following table:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Project} & \text{N. of programmers}  & \text{N. of analysts}  & \text{N. of terminals} \\
\hline
\text{A} & 2 & 2 & 3 \\
\text{B} & 3 & 6 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

The company wants to minimize the cost of developing projects in the next period. In the development of these projects, at least $10$ programmers and $5$ analysts should be used while the company only has $6$ terminals available. In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the company's activity?
answer1: $x_{i}$ is the number of developed project $i$ ($i=1$, for project $A$ and $i=2$, for project $B$)
answer2: $x_{2}$ is the number of developed projects $B$
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of developed projects $A$
answer4: $x$ is the number of developed projects $A$ and $B$

question:
The local extrema of the function
\[
f:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow\mathbb{R},\text{ }f(x,y)=6x^{2}y+2y^{3}-45x-51y+7
\]
is:
answer1: $\left(  \frac{3}{2},\frac{5}{2}\right)  $ is a local minimizer and $\left(  -\frac{3}{2},-\frac{5}{2}\right)  $ is a local maximizer.
answer4: $\left(  \frac{3}{2},\frac{5}{2}\right)  $ is a local maximizer and $\left(  -\frac{3}{2},-\frac{5}{2}\right)  $ is a local minimizer.

question:
Consider the linear applications 

$\begin{array}{cccc}
F: & \mathbb{R}^3 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y, z) & \longrightarrow & (y, x-z)
\end{array}$
$\begin{array}{cccc}
G: & \mathbb{R}^2 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y) & \longrightarrow & (x+y, x-2y)
\end{array}$

Choose the right answer:
answer1: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)$ does not exist
answer2: $(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$and $(G\circ F)$ does not exist
answer3: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$
answer4: $(G\circ F)(y, x-z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)(x, y)=(x+y, x-2y)$

question:

\text{Kilometers}&\text{Frequency} \\ 
\hline
0 -30 000& 15\\ 
30 001 - 60 000 & 25\\ 
60 001 - 90 000 & 60\\ 
 \hline

answer1: The sample range is at least $30 001$ but at most $90 000$.
answer3: The sample range is at least $30 000$ but  at most $90 000$.

x & + & 2y & = & 4 \\

The differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{2}\backslash \left\{ \left(
0,0\right) \right\} \rightarrow \mathbb{R},$ $f(x,y)=xy\ln \left(
x^{2}+y^{2}\right) $ satisfies the equation
answer1:
$x\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) +y\dfrac{\partial f}{%
\partial y}\left( x,y\right) =2\left( f(x,y)+xy\right) $
answer2:
$x\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) +y\dfrac{\partial f}{%
\partial y}\left( x,y\right) =2\left( f(x,y)-xy\right) $
answer3:
$x^{2}\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) +y\dfrac{\partial f}{%
\partial y}\left( x,y\right) =f(x,y)+xy$

question: Consider the linear transformation $F:\mathbb{R}^2 \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$, such that $F(x, y)=(x+2y, 2x+3y)$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(-3x+2y, 2x-y)$.
answer3: $F^{-1}$ is defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, -2x+y)$ and is not a symmetric operator.
answer4: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, 2x-y)$.

question:
Consider the table

$$\begin{array}{c|ccc}
x & 1 & 2 & 3   \\
\hline
y & 42 & 42.4 & 42.7 \\
\end{array} $$ 

Using Newton's polynomial, find the value of $P(1.5)$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 3y & + & 6z & = & a \\ 
3x & + & y & + & 3z & = & 1 \\ 
6x & + & 6y & + & z & = & 1 \\
7x & + & 9y & + & 7z & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions for $b\neq a+1$. 

If $b=a+1$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{37-14a}{100},\,\frac{3a-4}{20},\,\frac{1+3a}{25}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer2: The system has no solution for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
If $b\neq a+1$, the system has no solutions. 

Otherwise, for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{3+3a-z}{2},\,\frac{2+a-2z}{2},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
If $b=a+1$ the system has no solution. 

Otherwise, for every $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{a+b+1}{20},\,\frac{-a-b+2}{3},\,\frac{2a+3b-4}{15}\right)$.

question: Choose the true statement.
answer1: If $T:\mathbb{R}^2\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is a linear transformation, then $T$ can be an injection.
answer2: If $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$ is a linear transformation, then $T$ can be an injection.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x &  &  &+ &4z &= &0 \\ 
3x &- &4y &+ &12z &= &0 \\ 
x &- &2y &+ &5z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(-2z,\,\frac{3z}{2},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(-4,3,2\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(-2z+y,y,z\right)$ as solution for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Find the solution of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &5 \\ 
&5x &+ &3y &+ &2z &= &0 \\ 
&x &+ &y &- &z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer3: The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter.
answer4: The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & - & 4z & = & 2 \\ 
-x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\ 
x & + & 5y & - & 5z & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(\frac{1}{3}+\frac{5}{3}z,\,\frac{4}{3}+\frac{2}{3}z,\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has two solutions: $\left(1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ and $\left(0,\,2,\,-1\right)$.

question:
At the HealthPlus hospital, the nursing staff works in $6$ different shifts. Each shift has a duration of $8$ hours, with its start interval of $4$ hours (the first shift starts at $8:00$ AM, the second at $12:00$ AM, the third at $4:00$ p.m., and so on). The number of nurses required during the day is in the following table. How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning the nursing staff, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of nurses working in shift $i~(i = 1~to~6)$?

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|}
\hline
\text{Day period} & \text{Required number of nurses} \\
\hline
\text{8:00 a.m. to 12:00 a.m.} & 140 \\
\text{12:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.} & 120 \\
\text{4:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.} & 160 \\
\text{8:00 p.m. to 12:00 p.m.} & 90 \\
\text{12:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m.} & 30 \\
\text{4:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.} & 60 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]
answer2:
\[
		\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^5 x_{i}\\			
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 120\\			
		& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\
		&x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\
		&x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\
		&x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~5\\ 
		\end{array}
	     \]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
			\text{Maximize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 120\\
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 60\\
			& x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~6\\
			\end{array}
			\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll} 
				\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\			
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+x_{6}\geq 140\\			
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\			
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\			
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\			
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 60\\
			\end{array}
			\]

answer2: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & y & - & 3z & + & 2t & = & 1 \\
2x & - & y & - & z & + & t & = & 0 \\
x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{4}t-\frac{7}{12},\frac{3}{4}t-\frac{3}{4},t\bigg)$, for all $t\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},-\frac{7}{12},-\frac{3}{4},0\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer4: The solution of the system is the vector of coordinates $(2,-1,0,0)$.

question:

$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &0 \\ 
&3x &- &y &- &5z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer3:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$(3+z,2-2z,z),\, \forall z\in \mathbb{R}$$.

The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameter:
$$(3+z+y,y,z),\, \forall y,z\in \mathbb{R}$$.

Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x,y,z)=x^{2}yz-\cos \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}.$ Find $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}.$
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

question: Considering the similarity criteria of triangles, choose the correct statement.

answer3: Two right triangles are always similar.
answer4: Two scalene triangles are never similar.

\dfrac{\partial^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abxyf(x,y).$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2af(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abxyf(x,y).$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abf(x,y).$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4bxyf(x,y).$

question:
How many solutions does the following linear system have, with respect to $a\in\mathbb{R}$?
$$\left\{\begin{array}{cccccccc}
ax & + & y & + & 2az & = & a+5\\
ax & - & ay & - & z & = & a\\
x & - & ay & + & z & = & 3
\end{array}\right.$$
answer1: One solution for $a\neq 1$, and no solutions for $a=1$.
answer2: One solution for $a\neq 1,-1$, no solutions for $a=1$ and infinitely many solutions for $a=-1$.
answer4: No solutions for $a\neq 0$, and one solution for $a=0$.

$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & + & 2z & = & a \\
x & + & 2y & + & z & = & b \\
x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\
4x & + & 3y & + & 4z & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has solutions if and only if $a=-2$ and $b=5$. 
In this case, there is an infinite number of solution, which are of the form $\left(x,\,4,\,-3-x\right)$ for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer2:
The system has solutions if and only if $a \neq \frac{7}{4}$ and $b \neq \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the solutions are of the form $\left(\frac{3}{4}a-z,\,\frac{1}{4}b,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
The system has solutions if and only if $a = \frac{7}{4}$ and $b = \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the unique solution is $\left(\frac{3}{4},\,\frac{1}{4},\,0\right)$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system, given the values of the parameters $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x &- &4y &- &4z &= &\alpha \\ 
x &- &3y &- &z &= &\beta \\ 
2x &+ &4y &+ &z &= &\gamma
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{-\alpha+12\beta+8\gamma}{29},\,\frac{3\alpha-7\beta+5\gamma}{29},\,\frac{-10\alpha+4\beta-7\gamma}{29}\right)$.
answer2: The system has no solution for $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=0$, and for all other choices of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution which is $\left(\alpha+3\beta-\gamma,\,\gamma,\,\beta-\gamma\right)$.
answer3: The sistem has no solutions for every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$, the system has infinite solutions, which are $\left(\alpha-\beta+\gamma+z,\,1+z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

z'(t)=-x+2y+3z
\end{cases}$
answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{t}(\cos (t)-3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(3\cos (t)+\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+5C_{2}e^{t}\cos (t)+5C_{3}e^{t}\sin (t),
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.

answer2: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $t-\frac{1}{2}t^{2}+x+\ln|x|=0$.

answer4: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $t+\frac{1}{2}t^{2}+x-\ln|x|=0$.

For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.
	
In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the company's activity?
answer1: $x_{i}$ the number of units of product $i$ produced ($i=1$, for product $A$ and $i=2$, for product $B$).
answer2: $x$ the number of units of product $1$ and $2$ produced.
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of units of product $1$ produced.
answer4: $x_{2}$ is the number of units of product $2$ produced.

& C_1 & C_2 & C_3  &  C_4\\

\]

question:

x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\
3x & - & y & - & z & = & 4 \\
x & + & 5y & + & 5z & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(0,\,0,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(x,\,x,\,-2x+1\right)$ as solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(\frac{5}{4},\,y,\,z\right)$ as solution for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

A consulting firm will carry out two types of projects ($A$ and $B$). The development cost per project $A$ and $B$ is, respectively, $1$ and $2$ monetary units. The requirements in terms of analysts, programmers and terminals for each type of project are indicated in the following table:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Project} & \text{N. of programmers}  & \text{N. of analysts}  & \text{N. of terminals} \\
\hline
\text{A} & 2 & 2 & 3 \\
\text{B} & 3 & 6 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

The company wants to minimize the cost of developing projects in the next period. In the development of these projects, at least $10$ programmers and $5$ analysts should be used while the company only has $6$ terminals available. How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized  to allow planning the company's activity?

& S_1 & S_2 & S_3 \\
\hline

C_3 & 15 & 17 & 11 \\

\hline

\]

answer1: Tied optimal solutions: $x_{13} = 1,  x_{21} = 1, x_{32} = 1 \text{, other },  x_{ij}=0~$ or $~x_{13} = 1,  x_{22} = 1, x_{31} = 1 \text{, other }  x_{ij}=0$;

question:
A distribution company owns two warehouses (i) in the south of the country (W1 and W2). From these points, the company needs to supply its customers (j) in four cities, C1, C2, C3  and C4 (one customer per city). The transport cost for each tonne of material is 100 u.m./km. The following table shows the distances to be traveled between the two warehouses and the various cities (in km):

	\[
\begin{array}{l|cccc|}
& C_1 & C_2 & C_3  &  C_4\\
\hline
W_1 & 100 & 85 & 270  & 500 \\
W_2 & -  & 185 & 185 & 150\\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

The requirements of customers C1, C2, C3 and C4 are respectively 200, 250, 400 and 150 tonnes. The inventory in both warehouses W1 and W2 is 200 and 500 tonnes, respectively. The company has established agreements with the various customers, setting the following prices to charge (u.m./ton):

	\[
\begin{array}{l|cccc|}
& C_1 & C_2 & C_3  &  C_4\\
\hline
W_1 & 10500  & 9250 & 27570  & 50870\\
W_2 & - & 19150 & 18600 & 15220\\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

Determine the optimal solution, formulating a transport problem.

The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.
	
In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the company's activity?
answer1: $x_{i}$ the number of units of product $i$ produced ($i=1$, for product $A$ and $i=2$, for product $B$).
answer2: $x$ the number of units of product $1$ and $2$ produced.
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of units of product $1$ produced.
answer4: $x_{2}$ is the number of units of product $2$ produced.

question:

answer2: The $ABC$ plane has equation $x+y+1=0$ and $D=(4, -5, 7)$ belongs to $ABC$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & - & 4z & = & 0 \\
-x & + & y & + & z & = & 0 \\
x & + & 5y & - & 5z & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are $\left(\frac{5}{2}y,\,y,\,\frac{3}{2}y\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(5,2,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(0,\,0,\,0\right)$ as its unique solution.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 3y & + & 6z & = & a \\ 
3x & + & y & + & 3z & = & 1 \\ 
6x & + & 6y & + & z & = & 1 \\
7x & + & 9y & + & 7z & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions for $b\neq a+1$. 

If $b=a+1$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{37-14a}{100},\,\frac{3a-4}{20},\,\frac{1+3a}{25}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer2: The system has no solution for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
If $b\neq a+1$, the system has no solutions. 

Otherwise, for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{3+3a-z}{2},\,\frac{2+a-2z}{2},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
If $b=a+1$ the system has no solution. 

Otherwise, for every $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{a+b+1}{20},\,\frac{-a-b+2}{3},\,\frac{2a+3b-4}{15}\right)$.

\end{cases}$$

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & 2z & - & 3t & = & 1 \\ 
2x & + & y & - & 2z & - & t & = & 2 \\ 
x &- &3y &+ &z &- &2t &= &-1 \\
  &   &      &     &z &- &t &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(5,\,1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(5+20y,\,y,\,-10-13y,\,8+15y\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(5,0,-10,8\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:
How many solutions does the following linear system have, with respect to $a\in\mathbb{R}$?
$$\left\{\begin{array}{cccccccc}
ax & + & y & + & 2az & = & a+5\\
ax & - & ay & - & z & = & a\\
x & - & ay & + & z & = & 3
\end{array}\right.$$
answer1: One solution for $a\neq 1$, and no solutions for $a=1$.
answer2: One solution for $a\neq 1,-1$, no solutions for $a=1$ and infinitely many solutions for $a=-1$.
answer4: No solutions for $a\neq 0$, and one solution for $a=0$.

$$\begin{cases}
-x & + & y & + & z & = & a \\
&  & y & + & 3z & = & b \\
x &  &  & + & z & = & c
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every value of $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(a-b+2c,\,3a-2b+3c,\,-a+b-c\right)$.
answer3:
The system has no solution for $a\neq 0$. 
If $a=0$ and for every value of $b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(2c-b,\,3c-2b,\,b-c\right)$.
answer4: For every value of $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has $\left(1,\,1,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:
Ralph Edmund loves steaks and potatoes. Therefore, he has decided to go on a steady diet of only these two foods (plus some liquids and vitamin supplements) for all his meals. Ralph realizes that this isn't the healthiest diet, so he wants to make sure that he eats the right quantities of the two foods to satisfy some key nutritional requirements. He has obtained the following nutritional and cost information:

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline
%& \multicolumn{2}{c|}{Grams of ingredient per serving} &\\
\text{Ingredient} & \text{Steak (gr. per serving)} & \text{Potatoes (gr. per serving)} & \text{Daily Requirements (gr.)} \\
\hline
\text{Carbohydrates} & 5 & 15 & \geq 50 \\
\text{Protein} & 20 & 5 & \geq 40 \\
\text{Fat} & 15 & 2 & \leq 60 \\
\hline
\text{Cost per serving} & 4 & 2 &  \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the Ralph's diet?
answer1: $x_{i}$ is the number of daily servings of food $i$ ($i=1$, for steak and $i=2$, for potatoes)
answer2: $x$ is the number of daily servings of food
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of daily servings of potatoes
answer4: $x_{2}$ is the number of daily servings of steak

\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(1-2z-2t,\,-1-z,\,z,\,t\right)$ as solution for every $z,t\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1-2z,\,-1-z,\,z,\,0\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Solve the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 2z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
4x & + & y & - & 5z & - & 3w & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x-y,\,x+y+1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

\end{cases}$$

answer3: $F^{-1}$ is defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, -2x+y)$ and is not a symmetric operator.
answer4: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, 2x-y)$.

Consider the matrix 
$$A_k=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}
 1  & 1  & 0 \\
  -1 & -k  & k-1 \\

\end{array}\right]$$

answer1: If $k\in \mathbb{R}\backslash \{0, 1\}$ then the dimension of $L(A_k)$ is $3$

\end{array}\right.$$
answer1: The system has $(-1,0,0,-1)$ as unique solution.
answer3: The system has $(x, 0, 0, x)$ as solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & 2z & = & 2 \\
3x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
-x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has two solutions, $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ and $\left(2,\,1,\,0\right)$.
answer4: The system has an infinite number of solutions, which are of the form $\left(-4+z,\,z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer3: $\dfrac{\partial z}{\partial x}=2x y^2 e^{x^2 y^3}, \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial y}=3x^2 y^2 e^{x y}$
answer4: $\dfrac{\partial z}{\partial x}=x y^3 e^{x^2 y^3}, \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial y}=x^2 y^2 e^{x^2 y^3}$

question:
For which values of $m\in\mathbb{R}$ does the following linear system has a solution?
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & my & + & m^{2}z & = & m \\
mx & - & m^{2}y & + & mz & = & 1 \\
mx & + & y & - & m^{3}z & = & -1
\end{cases}$$

Find the solution of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &0 \\ 
&3x &- &y &- &5z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer3:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$(3+z,2-2z,z),\, \forall z\in \mathbb{R}$$.
answer4:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameter:
$$(3+z+y,y,z),\, \forall y,z\in \mathbb{R}$$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
ax & + & y & = & 1 \\ 
bx & + & y & = & 2 \\ 
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
If $b=a$, the system has no solution. 

If $b\neq a$, the system has $\left(\frac{1}{b-a},\,\frac{b-2a}{b-a}\right)$ as its unique solution
answer2: The system has no solutions for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
The system has no solutions if $a,b\neq 1$. 

If $a=b=1$, the system has $\left(x,\,\frac{x}{2}\right)$ as solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has $\left(a-b+x,\,\frac{b-a+x}{2}\right)$ as its unique solution.

question: Find the integral curve which satisfies the equation $tx'-x=-2t^2x^2$ with initial condition $x(1)=1$.

answer2: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $x(2t^3+3)-t=0$.
answer3: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $\frac{x}{2t^3+1}-3t=0$.
answer4: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $x=\frac{2t^3+1}{3t}$.

\end{cases}$$

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & 2z & = & 2 \\
3x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
-x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has two solutions, $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ and $\left(2,\,1,\,0\right)$.
answer4: The system has an infinite number of solutions, which are of the form $\left(-4+z,\,z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question: Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x,y,z)=x^{2}yz-\cos \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}.$ Find $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}.$
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

question: Find the integral curve which satisfies the equation $tx'-x=-2t^2x^2$ with initial condition $x(1)=1$.

answer3: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $\frac{x}{2t^3+1}-3t=0$.

The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.

How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning of the company's activity?
answer1:
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
	        & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			& x_{2}\leq 60\\
			&  x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
			    & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\leq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
    			& 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\geq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
3x & - & y & - & 2z & = & a \\
-x & + & 3y & - & z & = & b \\
-2x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
x & - & 3y & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a \neq 1$ and $b \neq -1$.
If $a=1$ and $b=-1$, then the system has $\left(\frac{2+7z}{8},\,\frac{-2+5z}{8},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,1,\,0\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4:
The system has no solution if $a\neq 1$ and $b\neq 1$. 
If $a=b=1$, the system has $\left(1+y,\,y,\,\frac{3+y}{4}\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Find the general solution for the differential equation system

$\begin{cases}
x'(t)=2x+y \\
y'(t)=x+3y-z \\
z'(t)=-x+2y+3z
\end{cases}$
answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{t}(\cos (t)-3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(3\cos (t)+\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+5C_{2}e^{t}\cos (t)+5C_{3}e^{t}\sin (t),
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.

\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3},y, -\frac{1}{3}\right),\, \forall y\in\mathbb{R}$$.
answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & y & - & 3z & + & 2t & = & 1 \\
2x & - & y & - & z & + & t & = & 0 \\
x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{4}t-\frac{7}{12},\frac{3}{4}t-\frac{3}{4},t\bigg)$, for all $t\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},-\frac{7}{12},-\frac{3}{4},0\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer4: The solution of the system is the vector of coordinates $(2,-1,0,0)$.

answer1:
If $b=a$, the system has no solution. 

If $b\neq a$, the system has $\left(\frac{1}{b-a},\,\frac{b-2a}{b-a}\right)$ as its unique solution
answer2: The system has no solutions for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
The system has no solutions if $a,b\neq 1$. 

If $a=b=1$, the system has $\left(x,\,\frac{x}{2}\right)$ as solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has $\left(a-b+x,\,\frac{b-a+x}{2}\right)$ as its unique solution.

$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
3x & - & y & - & 2z & = & a \\
-x & + & 3y & - & z & = & b \\
-2x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
x & - & 3y & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a \neq 1$ and $b \neq -1$.
If $a=1$ and $b=-1$, then the system has $\left(\frac{2+7z}{8},\,\frac{-2+5z}{8},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,1,\,0\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4:
The system has no solution if $a\neq 1$ and $b\neq 1$. 
If $a=b=1$, the system has $\left(1+y,\,y,\,\frac{3+y}{4}\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
The staff of a seaport works 8 hours a day, two blocks of 4 hours, obligatorily separated by 1 hour to rest. Given the 24 hours a day, the company has to hire six shifts with a 4-hour interval start (e.g. the 1st shift starts at 0:00 a.m., the 2nd at 4 a.m., the 3rd at 8:00 a.m., ..., the 6th at 8:00 p.m.). Supposing that the number of workers required to the proper functioning of the port is indicated in the following table:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|l|c|}
	\hline
	\text{Day period} & \text{Required number of workers} \\
	\hline
	\text{0:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.} & 10 \\
	\text{8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.} & 40\\
	\text{4:00 p.m. to 0:00 a.m.} & 20 \\
	\hline
	\end{array}
	\]

How does the linear programming model should be formalized to allow planning the proper functioning of the port, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of  workers in shift $i~(i = 1~to~6)$?
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}	
			\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 10\\
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 40\\
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 40\\
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 20\\
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 20\\
			& x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~6\\
			\end{array}
			\]

Letting $j := e^{\frac{2i\pi}{3}}$, find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & - & z & = & 0 \\ 
x & + & jy & + & j^{2}z & = & a \\ 
 &  & j^{2}y & + & jz & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a+b\neq 0$. 

If $b=-a$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer2: The system has no solution for every value of $a$ and $b$.
answer3: The system has $\left(0,0,0\right)$ as its unique solution if $a=b=0$, and for all other values of $a$ and $b$ the system has no solutions.
answer4: For every $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x & + & y & + & z & = & a \\
&  & y & + & 3z & = & b \\
x &  &  & + & z & = & c
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every value of $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(a-b+2c,\,3a-2b+3c,\,-a+b-c\right)$.
answer3:
The system has no solution for $a\neq 0$.

question:
Find the solution of the following system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &-1 \\ 
&x &+ &y &- &5z &= &2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3},y, -\frac{1}{3}\right),\, \forall y\in\mathbb{R}$$.
answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

question: Solving an integer programming problem by rounding off answers obtained by solving it as a linear programming problem (using simplex), it is possible to conclude that
answer1: the value of the objective function for a maximization problem will likely be less than the simplex solution.
answer2: the values of decision variables obtained by rounding off are always very close to the optimal values.
answer3: the value of the objective function for a minimization problem will likely be less than the simplex solution.

question:
The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.

How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning of the company's activity?
answer1:
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
	        & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			& x_{2}\leq 60\\
			&  x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
			    & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\leq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
    			& 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\geq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
